Expectation1: Offer help or support when asked
Situation1: An acquaintance asks for a recommendation on a good restaurant in the area.
Expectation2: Greet clients and make them feel comfortable
Situation2: A familiar customer strolls in while the receptionist is free to chat.
Story:
I was just finishing up a quick trim on a regular client when I spotted Mark, an old acquaintance from college, waving at me from the waiting area. He grinned and called out, “Hey! Do you know any good places to eat around here?” I could see he was hoping for a real conversation, maybe even a little catch-up. At the same moment, Mrs. Lee, one of my most loyal customers, walked in. The receptionist was free, but Mrs. Lee always expected a personal greeting from me—she said it made her feel special, and I knew it was part of why she kept coming back.

I felt my stomach twist. Mark was waiting for my answer, his eyes bright with expectation, and I didn’t want to brush him off. But Mrs. Lee was already looking around, searching for my face, and I knew she’d be disappointed if I didn’t greet her right away. I could feel the pressure mounting, torn between being the helpful acquaintance Mark remembered and the attentive hairdresser Mrs. Lee counted on. My mind raced, trying to figure out how to be both at once, but I knew I couldn’t give them both what they wanted in that moment.
